Actually, presuming I guess correctly about what happened, you almost
get it below:

> My confusion comes (I think) from the fact that I am trying to make
> my UI "lightweight" in terms of functionality embedded within it. So
> from that viewpoint the effect I am interested in is that my edit
> control behaves correctly. So the UI code becomes responsible for
> instantiating and using this text contol. Perhaps a better (more TDD
> friendly?) approach would be to realise that I needed a text control
> to be have in a certain manner and extract that from my UI and drive
> that? Having said that I'd still probably have nested the
> construction of the DocumentListeners, so I'd still end up with the
> same [quandary]

Right, but presumably 

* there is a reason why you needed to"nested the construction of the
  DocumentListeners" as you did. Presuming that non-atomic operation
  is goal-directed, let's call its goal "foo-optimality."

* there is (at least one) right way and wrong way to attain
  foo-optimality (as you have found)

* your UI seeks to cause foo-optimality (bring to foo-ition ?-), and
  possibly report on some aspect of foo-ness to the user.

Therefore I'm suggesting that you might want to consider if it's worth
the effort to

>> 4) expose API to getEffectDesired() 

0 write some expressive, relatively-atomic API, e.g.
  attainFooOptimality(...) that does what your UI wanted, and does it
  correctly (darn those pesky DocumentListeners !-) This would
  presumably be reusable in future (or is foo-optimality some passing
  fancy?)

>> and then testGettingEffectDesired()

1 red/green/refactor that API

2 call that API from your UI ("lightening its weight")

as well as keeping your implementation-neutral UI testcase, keeping in
mind the correct, general rule that

J. B. Rainsberger Mon, 07 Jun 2004 18:11:30 -0400
> in the long run, and as a general practice, you /want/ both tests.

as well as the facts that all practices are specific, and in the long
run, we're all dead :-)
